sections.1_story_intuition: Indian Space Research, led by ISRO, has made India a global leader in space technology. ISRO's achievements include launching satellites, interplanetary missions, and developing indigenous technology. This topic is important for competitive exams, covering key missions, scientists, and milestones in India's space journey.
2_key_definitions: ISRO: Indian Space Research Organisation, India's space agency.
Satellite: An object placed in orbit around Earth or another planet.
Launch Vehicle: Rocket used to carry satellites into space.
PSLV: Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle, a major ISRO rocket.
Remote Sensing: Collecting data from satellites.
Cryogenic Engine: Advanced rocket engine using super-cooled fuels.
3_key_facts_data_points: ISRO founded in 1969 by Dr. Vikram Sarabhai.
Rohini-1: First satellite launched by India (1980).
Chandrayaan-2: Lunar mission with orbiter, lander, rover (2019).
India: First Asian country to reach Mars orbit.
Cartosat: Series of remote sensing satellites.
Satish Dhawan Space Centre: Main spaceport (Sriharikota).
Dr. K. Sivan: Former ISRO Chairman.
5_exam_capsules: Who founded ISRO? Dr. Vikram Sarabhai.
What was India's first satellite? Aryabhata.
What is PSLV? Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle.
What is GSLV? Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle.
What was Chandrayaan-1? First lunar mission.
What is Mangalyaan? Mars Orbiter Mission.
Who is the current ISRO Chairman? S. Somanath.
Where is Satish Dhawan Space Centre? Sriharikota.
What is Gaganyaan? Human spaceflight mission.
What is a cryogenic engine? Advanced rocket engine.
What is INSAT? Indian National Satellite System.
How many foreign satellites has ISRO launched? 100+.
What is remote sensing? Data collection from satellites.
7_traps_confusing_points: Assuming all satellites are for communication.
Mixing up ISRO and NASA missions.
Assuming all launches are from the same site.
Confusing cryogenic and solid fuel engines.

8_case_study_context.title: Chandrayaan-3: India's Moon Landing
8_case_study_context.explanation: Chandrayaan-3, launched in 2023, achieved a successful soft landing on the Moon. This mission demonstrated India's growing expertise in space technology and made India the fourth country to achieve a lunar landing.
